newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Rato says new data show strong jobs trend.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Rato says new data show strong jobs trend.

text.p: Spanish Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato said on Thursday the latest employment data show steady, strong job creation.
"The important thing is there is a steady trend (of employment). Unemployment has been falling since February. The creation of new jobs is very strong in Spain," Rato said in a radio interview.
Earlier, Spain's Labour Ministry said the April jobless rate fell to 13.61 percent from 13.89 percent in March.
Rato reiterated the centre-right government expects 240,000 to 260,000 new jobs to be added to the economy during 1997.
"I think that 1997 can be a year during which around 240,000-260,000 new jobs can be created at a rate of growth we can mantain for many years with a very tame inflation rate," Rato said.
